Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for U.S. Participants Attending the Eighth Conference of the International Marangoni Association

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1640677
PI: Narayanan, Ranga

This award will support participation of scientists and engineers at the Eighth Conference of the International Marangoni Association, which will be held June 12-16, 2016 in Ban Honnef, Germany. The theme of the eighth conference in this series is Interfacial Fluid Dynamics and Processes. The conference will focus on industrial and practical applications in materials processing, biological transport and environmental remediation. Fundamental problems to be addressed include crystal growth and solidification, gas-liquid systems, bubble dynamics in glass processing, and multiphase flow phenomena in a variety of applications. The conference will have a balance of speakers from academia and industry and will be organized to promote connections between academic investigators and their international industrial counterparts. Support will be provided to emerging scientists, including students, post-docs, and junior faculty to help increase their participation.

Session topics will focus at the interface of research and industrial practice and will include evaporation and drying, liquid bridges, droplet formation and spreading, particle accumulation and coating films, layered fluids, surfactants and foams, and electrohydrodynamics. The proceedings of the conference will be published in the European Journal of Physics. Encouraging the participation of young investigators will help fill a national need to train a future work force in interfacial fluid mechanics and will provide a unique opportunity for young investigators to interact with leading researchers and industrial practitioners in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major activity of the project was to present papers at the eighth international workshop and con- ference on interfacial fluid mechanics and transport processes. In this regard we must note that several participants also gave posters including many senior authors.

The specific objectives were to allow the exchange of ideas and create avenues for future collabora- tion. Several papers that were presented were critiqued and have resulted in publications. Key outcomes included new collaborations between the participants who received funding and several other conference attendees were established. These included collaborations with Univ. Paris, Univ. Lille, Indian Inst. Sci- ence Bangalore, and Univ. Darmstadt. The workshop provided an avenue for the professional development of young scientists, both graduate students and post doctoral scientists. These young scientists presented papers and communicated their ideas to an audience of international experts, many of whom were mem- bers of national academies and fellows of major professional societies. The results of these presentations have been submitted or published in doctoral theses and archival journals.

 

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the proposed activity included significant results such as the adoption of new the- ories on phase change and contact-line dynamics, new ideas on stabilization via heat transport in thermo- capillary systems and ideas on pattern interference via geometry in interfacial problems.

 

 

Broader Impacts

New collaborations among scientists were established. This was particularly true between Europe and the US and the US and Japan. The new collaborations include a) Pattern resonance for determining Surface Tension on the International Space Station (with Japan) and b) patterns for micro-fluidics (with Univ. Lille in France).

 

Products that acknowledge Federal Support

 

X.Lin, L.E. Johns, and R. Narayanan, "Static Stability of Pendent Drops Pinned to Arbitrary Closed Curves"  to appear Phys. Rev. Fluids (2017)

J. Picardo and R. Narayanan, "Pattern selection in defiance of linear growth", J. Fluid Mech. 829, 345-363, (2017)

D. Pillai and R. Narayanan, "Interfacial Dynamics of a Liquid Vapor Bilayer Undergoing Evaporation", Under review, J. Fluid Mechanics

K. L. Ward, S. Matsumoto and R. Narayanan, "Electrostatically Forced Faraday Instability" submitted to J. Fluid Mechanics

 

 

The impact on the development of the principal discipline of the project

 

The conference was principally in the field of applications of interfacial fluid mechanics. Several new ideas on the role of mass transfer on interfacial instability and the subsequent delay in critical heat flux in heat exchangers with phase change were presented. Other ideas that developed from the conference included the role of resonant forcing on instabilities and their applications to the measurement of surface tension for materials at very high temperatures, such as liquid metals. These ideas, in turn, have led to research that has been submitted for publication.

 

Impact on the development of human resources, resources that form infrastructure,and technology transfer.

 

Several students and young scientists benefitted by enhancing communication skills and more important by developing new ideas that have helped with their research. The resources that have enhanced infrastructure included the development of methods that can practically solve interfacial problems associated with thin films. Some of the findings related Interfacail Energy measurements and reported to the conference have been transferred to technology via an invention disclosure.
